title: 112_s1616
content: The Act titled "Real Estate Investment and Jobs Act of 2011" provides an exception from FIRPTA for certain stock of Real Estate Investment Trusts. The Real Estate Investment and Jobs Act of 2011 amends section 897(c) of the Internal Revenue Code to provide exceptions for certain stock of Real Estate Investment Trusts, including an exception for stock regularly traded on established securities markets and an exception for certain stock held by a qualified entity. The Real Estate Investment and Jobs Act of 2011 amends section 897(c) of the Internal Revenue Code to provide exceptions for certain stock of Real Estate Investment Trusts. A qualified shareholder's investment in a real estate investment trust is not considered a United States real property interest unless an investor (other than a qualified shareholder) holds more than 10 percent of the stock indirectly. A qualified shareholder is an entity eligible for benefits of a comprehensive income tax treaty. The Real Estate Investment and Jobs Act of 2011 amends the Internal Revenue Code to exempt certain stock of Real Estate Investment Trusts from being considered a United States real property interest. A qualified shareholder is an entity eligible for benefits of a comprehensive income tax treaty with the United States, including an exchange of information program, being a qualified collective investment vehicle with interests listed on recognized stock exchanges, and maintaining records on shareholders. The Real Estate Investment and Jobs Act of 2011 amends the Internal Revenue Code to exempt certain stock of Real Estate Investment Trusts from being considered a United States real property interest. A qualified shareholder is an entity eligible for benefits of a comprehensive income tax treaty with the United States, including an exchange of information program, being a qualified collective investment vehicle with interests listed on recognized stock exchanges, and maintaining records on shareholders. A qualified collective investment vehicle is an entity that would be eligible for a reduced rate of withholding under such comprehensive income tax treaty with respect to ordinary dividends paid by a real estate investment trust, even if such entity holds more than 10 percent of the stock of such real estate. This exemption applies to stock that would be classified as a United States real property holding corporation or designated as such by the Secretary, and is fiscally transparent within the meaning of section 894. The Real Estate Investment and Jobs Act of 2011 amends the Internal Revenue Code to exempt certain stock of Real Estate Investment Trusts from being considered a United States real property interest. The amendment includes provisions for distributions by Real Estate Investment Trusts, with specific criteria for qualifying distributions. The Real Estate Investment and Jobs Act of 2011 amends the Internal Revenue Code to exempt certain stock of Real Estate Investment Trusts from being considered a United States real property interest. The amendment includes provisions for distributions by Real Estate Investment Trusts, with specific criteria for qualifying distributions, such as not treating distributions as gain recognized from the sale or exchange of a United States real property interest under certain conditions. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to define the control of qualified investment entities. Stock held by one entity is considered foreign-owned unless the holding entity is domestically controlled. A qualified investment entity can presume that stock held by a holder of less than 5 percent on a US securities market is held by US persons. Amendments are made to ensure compliance with the code. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to change the threshold from "more than 5 percent" to "more than 5 or 10 percent, whichever is applicable" and to adjust the substitution from "5 percent" to "5 percent or 10 percent, whichever is applicable." The effective dates for these amendments are specified for dispositions and distributions by real estate investment trusts. The amendments made by subsections (c) and (d) will take effect on the date of the enactment of this Act. The amendment excludes certain interests in corporations from being considered as United States real property interest under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. This change will take effect upon the enactment of the Act.
